question.title: The problem with Georgian language in javafx.scene.web.WebView
question.body:
I have a problem with Georgian language in javafx.scene.web.WebView. It is displayed as squares. Here is an example of code:

    public void start(Stage stage) throws IOException {
        FXMLLoader fxmlLoader = new FXMLLoader(HelloApplication.class.getResource("hello-view.fxml"));
        Scene scene = new Scene(fxmlLoader.load(), 320, 240);
        WebView webView = (WebView) scene.lookup("#web");
        WebEngine engine = webView.getEngine();
        String html = """
            გამარჯობა, ეს არის ტესტი.
            """;
        engine.loadContent(html);


        stage.setTitle("Hello!");
        stage.setScene(scene);
        stage.show();
    }

and result:

I use

       <dependency>
            <groupId>org.openjfx</groupId>
            <artifactId>javafx-web</artifactId>
            <version>23.0.2</version>
        </dependency>

answers.body:
Reproducing Problem

Skip to the end of the answer if you want to see a solution/workaround to the problem.

I can reproduce the problem using Java 24.0.1 and JavaFX 24.0.1 on Windows 10 with the following code:

package com.example;

import javafx.application.Application;
import javafx.scene.Scene;
import javafx.scene.web.WebView;
import javafx.stage.Stage;

public class Main extends Application {

  private static final String HTML_PAGE =
      """
          <!DOCTYPE html>
          
          <html>
            <head>
              <title>Unicode Rendering Test</title>
              <meta charset="UTF-8"/>
            </head>
            <body>
              <h1>Welcome</h1>
              <p>გამარჯობა, ეს არის ტესტი.</p>
            </body>
          </html>
          """;

  @Override
  public void start(Stage primaryStage) {
    var webView = new WebView();
    webView.getEngine().loadContent(HTML_PAGE);

    primaryStage.setScene(new Scene(webView, 500, 300));
    primaryStage.show();
  }

  public static void main(String[] args) {
    launch(Main.class);
  }
}

Using a well-formed HTML document and specifying the encoding helps isolate the problem. It now seems pretty clear that JavaFX's WebView is failing to use a font that can display Georgian characters.

And here's the Maven POM I used to run the example:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0"
         xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
         xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0 http://maven.apache.org/xsd/maven-4.0.0.xsd">
    <modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion>

    <groupId>com.example</groupId>
    <artifactId>example</artifactId>
    <version>0.1.0</version>

    <properties>
        <project.build.sourceEncoding>UTF-8</project.build.sourceEncoding>
        <maven.compiler.release>24</maven.compiler.release>
        <javafx.version>24.0.1</javafx.version>
    </properties>

    <build>
        <plugins>
            <plugin>
                <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
                <artifactId>maven-compiler-plugin</artifactId>
                <version>3.14.0</version>
            </plugin>

            <plugin>
                <groupId>org.openjfx</groupId>
                <artifactId>javafx-maven-plugin</artifactId>
                <version>0.0.8</version>
                <configuration>
                    <mainClass>com.example.Main</mainClass>
                    <options>
                        <option>--enable-native-access=javafx.graphics,javafx.media,javafx.web</option>
                        <option>--sun-misc-unsafe-memory-access=allow</option>
                    </options>
                </configuration>
            </plugin>
        </plugins>
    </build>

    <dependencies>
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.openjfx</groupId>
            <artifactId>javafx-web</artifactId>
            <version>${javafx.version}</version>
        </dependency>
    </dependencies>
</project>

Output of mvn javafx:run:

Other Browsers

Loading the HTML in the following browsers (on Windows 10) displays the Georgian characters correctly:

  • Edge
  • Chrome
  • Firefox
  • IntelliJ IDEA's built-in web view

The answer by Basil Bourque shows it working on macOS with Safari. This is particularly interesting because Safari's web engine is WebKit which is the same web engine used by JavaFX (I don't know if the two implementations are exactly the same).

A Bug

A noted by Basil Bourque and VGR in the comments (and Basil's answer), this seems to be a bug with JavaFX's WebView. At the very least, this is a questionable implementation choice by JavaFX.

Not a “simple font issue”. Selection of a fallback font for those characters should be automatic. HTML content is not responsible for finding fonts to render the contained characters. Adding a font name within your HTML content is a workaround for a bug.

The HTML/CSS author can guide the runtime through a list of preferred fonts (a “font stack”) that may or may not exist on the runtime machine. If none of those suggested fonts provide a glyph for a particular character, the web browser and host OS should find some other font with the needed glyphs. Only if there is no font at all available at runtime offering those glyphs should we see boxes/questions/blanks.

– Basil Bourque

It’s pretty clear that this has nothing to do with encodings. Basil is mostly correct in that WebKit is not doing its due diligence; its default stylesheet should search all available fonts in order to maximize Unicode coverage. I don’t think the HTML or CSS standards require doing that, so I don’t know if it’s a bug as much as a poor renderer design. Specifying font-family is a workaround which should not be necessary.

– VGR

There's also this old bug: JDK-8087702 – Georgian font is not rendered. That bug report says it occurs on Windows 8 and was created back in 2014, which means this has been a problem since JavaFX 8.

I don't know if the bug is in JavaFX itself or the underlying WebKit engine.

Platform specific

This erroneous behavior would appear to be platform-specific. The Georgian characters are not displayed correctly by JavaFX's WebView on Windows, but Basil's answer shows them being displayed correctly on macOS using essentially the same code.

Font Fallback

As I understand it, the web engine should automatically pick a font that can display the characters on a web page. And this should happen for each individual character. At least, this seems to be the case when using font-family. From the documentation at https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/font-family :

Values are separated by commas to indicate that they are alternatives. The browser will select the first font in the list that is installed or that can be downloaded using a @font-face at-rule.

[...]

You should always include at least one generic family name in a font-family list, since there's no guarantee that any given font is available. This lets the browser select an acceptable fallback font when necessary.

The font-family property specifies a list of fonts, from highest priority to lowest. Font selection does not stop at the first font in the list that is on the user's system. Rather, font selection is done one character at a time, so that if an available font does not have a glyph for a needed character, the latter fonts are tried. When a font is only available in some styles, variants, or sizes, those properties may also influence which font family is chosen.

But I could not find much information (which doesn't mean it doesn't exist) about what happens if no font-family is defined by the webpage. From what I could gather, either web browsers should have a default stylesheet that defines font-family or web browsers will typically fall back to a user-defined or system-wide default font (whatever font that may be). Maybe it's a combination of the two. Either way, it may be that the default font chosen by JavaFX's WebView does not have glyphs for Georgian characters.

However, as noted by Basil, modern operating systems like Windows, macOS, and Linux should have their own font fallback mechanism. For Windows, this would seem to be provided by DirectWrite.

The DirectWrite font system provides services for dealing with font enumeration, font fallback [emphasis added], and font caching, which are all needed by applications for handling fonts.

And JavaFX's WebView should be hooking into this mechanism when no font is specifically applied by the webpage, or if only a font family is specified. One thing to note is that even if you have:

font-family: sans-serif;

Which defines a font family, JavaFX's WebView still fails to pick an appropriate font to display each character.

There seems to be a few bugs and enhancement requests about font fallback in JavaFX which may be related to the problem with WebView:

  • JDK-8298492 – Add more fallbacks to System font
  • JDK-8091604 – Use same font fall backs as CoreText on Mac OS X
  • JDK-8217392 – Need more code point coverage in composite fonts on Windows.
  • JDK-8198752 – Figure out how to handle the fallback if fonts are not present in jdk-home/lib/fonts directory
  • And more. You can browse the bug database yourself if interested.

The linked bugs seem more about javafx.scene.text.Font, but the issues may be bleeding over into WebView.

Solution (Workaround)

One solution is to explicitly define a font that can display Georgian characters. This was suggested in a comment by VGR.

Does it work if you change the HTML string to this? <span style="font-family: 'Segoe UI';">გამარჯობა, ეს არის ტესტი.</span>

You can implement this inline like in VGR's comment, in an embedded stylesheet, or in an external stylesheet. Here's an example using an embedded stylesheet (note the only change from code shown earlier is the <style> element in the HTML document string):

package com.example;

import javafx.application.Application;
import javafx.scene.Scene;
import javafx.scene.web.WebView;
import javafx.stage.Stage;

public class Main extends Application {

  private static final String HTML_PAGE =
      """
          <!DOCTYPE html>
          
          <html>
            <head>
              <title>Unicode Rendering Test</title>
              <meta charset="UTF-8"/>
          
              <style>
              body {
                font-family: 'Segoe UI', sans-serif;
              }
              </style>
          
            </head>
            <body>
              <h1>Welcome</h1>
              <p>გამარჯობა, ეს არის ტესტი.</p>
            </body>
          </html>
          """;

  @Override
  public void start(Stage primaryStage) {
    var webView = new WebView();
    webView.getEngine().loadContent(HTML_PAGE);

    primaryStage.setScene(new Scene(webView, 500, 300));
    primaryStage.show();
  }

  public static void main(String[] args) {
    launch(Main.class);
  }
}

And the Maven POM file used to run the above (unchanged from POM shown earlier):

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0"
         xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
         xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0 http://maven.apache.org/xsd/maven-4.0.0.xsd">
    <modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion>

    <groupId>com.example</groupId>
    <artifactId>example</artifactId>
    <version>0.1.0</version>

    <properties>
        <project.build.sourceEncoding>UTF-8</project.build.sourceEncoding>
        <maven.compiler.release>24</maven.compiler.release>
        <javafx.version>24.0.1</javafx.version>
    </properties>

    <build>
        <plugins>
            <plugin>
                <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
                <artifactId>maven-compiler-plugin</artifactId>
                <version>3.14.0</version>
            </plugin>

            <plugin>
                <groupId>org.openjfx</groupId>
                <artifactId>javafx-maven-plugin</artifactId>
                <version>0.0.8</version>
                <configuration>
                    <mainClass>com.example.Main</mainClass>
                    <options>
                        <option>--enable-native-access=javafx.graphics,javafx.media,javafx.web</option>
                        <option>--sun-misc-unsafe-memory-access=allow</option>
                    </options>
                </configuration>
            </plugin>
        </plugins>
    </build>

    <dependencies>
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.openjfx</groupId>
            <artifactId>javafx-web</artifactId>
            <version>${javafx.version}</version>
        </dependency>
    </dependencies>
</project>

Output of mvn javafx:run:

Note you can define the font-family in an external stylesheet and set it to the WebEngine.userStylesheetLocation property. This will apply the fix to all webpages loaded by the WebEngine. Though keep in mind that if the webpage itself defines a font-family then that value will override the user stylesheet.

It may be that WebEngine.userStylesheetLocation is intended to be the default stylesheet that each browser should have. Which means it's the responsibility of the application developer to add one. However, the fact that defining the font family as something like sans-serif doesn't work is (likely) still a bug.

I suspect the solution shown in the Answer by Slaw is actually a workaround for some kind of bug.

The key point in that solution is specifying a font. This was done with an embedded CSS stylesheet. This should not necessary, hence my point about being a workaround for a bug.

Web content is not responsible for identifying a font containing necessary glyphs for particular characters. That is a job for the user-agent and the host OS. So I suspect the bug biting you lives somewhere within JavaFX/OpenJFX, the WebView component, the WebKit implementation backing the WebView component, the host OS, or some combination therein.

Working example app

To show a complete working example that runs successfully on macOS Sequoia, as well as to help you in debugging, I present this example app. Nowhere in this code we specify a font.

I began with a new JavaFX project created by the JavaFX template in the IntelliJ IDE. I modified the POM, the module-info.java, and the HelloApplication.java file. I ignored the FXML and HelloController.java.

First test is to look at your problematic text within your code editor.

If you see the text appear correctly, you know your computer does indeed have at least one font available containing glyphs for those characters.

If your IDE is Java-based such as IntelliJ and NetBeans, then you also know that the JVM running your IDE is able to access at least one such font.

At runtime, this app writes a file with HTML5 for display of our problematic text. A WebView component opens this file, and renders the web page.

You can see here that in my WebView component instance, I get properly rendered page content including your problematic text. I used Java 24.0.1 with an early-access release of JavaFX/OpenJFX 25. I ran on macOS Sequoia 15.4.1 on a MacBook Pro with Apple M1 Pro chip.

Click the Open in web browser button to open that very same HTML5 document into your default web browser. For me that was Safari 18.4.

Again, success for me.

My point here is that the HTML content I used here does not specify any fonts. The user-agent (WebView component backed by WebKit) worked with the host OS to find an appropriate font with glyphs for your desired characters.

Source code

The JavaFX code:

package work.basil.example.webviewfontproblem;

import javafx.application.Application;
import javafx.scene.Scene;
import javafx.scene.control.Button;
import javafx.scene.control.Label;
import javafx.scene.layout.VBox;
import javafx.scene.web.WebView;
import javafx.stage.Stage;

import java.io.IOException;
import java.nio.charset.StandardCharsets;
import java.nio.file.Files;
import java.nio.file.Path;
import java.time.Instant;

public class HelloApplication extends Application
{
    @Override
    public void start ( final Stage stage )
    {
        final Path pathToHtmlFile = writeHtml ( );

        // Widgets
        Label pathLabel = new Label ( "Path to HTML file: " + pathToHtmlFile.toAbsolutePath ( ) );

        Button button = new Button ( );
        button.setText ( "Open in web browser" );
        button.setOnAction ( _ -> getHostServices ( ).showDocument ( pathToHtmlFile.toAbsolutePath ( ).toString ( ) ) );  // Open file in web browser.

        WebView webView = new WebView ( );
        String url = pathToHtmlFile.toUri ( ).toASCIIString ( );
        webView.getEngine ( ).load ( url );

        // Arrange
        stage.setTitle ( "WebView Font Problem" );
        VBox root = new VBox ( 12 );
        root.setAlignment ( javafx.geometry.Pos.CENTER );
        root.getChildren ( ).addAll ( pathLabel , webView , button );
        stage.setScene ( new Scene ( root , 900 , 200 ) );
        stage.show ( );
    }

    private Path writeHtml ( )
    {
        System.out.println ( "INFO - Writing HTML file. " + Instant.now ( ) );
        try
        {
            final Path pathToHtmlFile = Files.createTempFile ( "WebViewFontProblem_" , ".html" );
            System.out.println ( "INFO - Writing HTML file to " + pathToHtmlFile.toAbsolutePath ( ) + " at " + Instant.now ( ) );
            String html = """
                    <!DOCTYPE html>
                    <html>
                    <head>
                      <title>Unicode Rendering Test</title>
                      <meta charset="UTF-8"/>
                    </head>
                    <body>
                      <h1>Welcome</h1>
                      <p>გამარჯობა, ეს არის ტესტი.</p>
                    </body>
                    </html>
                    """;
            final Path path =
                    Files.writeString (
                            pathToHtmlFile ,
                            html ,
                            StandardCharsets.UTF_8
                    );
            System.out.println ( "INFO - Path to HTML file: " + pathToHtmlFile.toAbsolutePath ( ) + " written  at " + Instant.now ( ) );
            path.toFile ( ).deleteOnExit ( );  // Eventually delete the file, as the JVM exits.
            return path;
        }
        catch ( IOException e )
        {
            throw new RuntimeException ( e );
        }
    }

    public static void main ( String[] args )
    {
        launch ( );
    }
}

The module-info.java file:

module work.basil.example.webviewfontproblem {
    requires javafx.controls;
    requires javafx.web;
    requires javafx.fxml;
    requires javafx.base;
    requires javafx.graphics;

    opens work.basil.example.webviewfontproblem to javafx.fxml;
    exports work.basil.example.webviewfontproblem;
}

And my Maven POM:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0"
         xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
         xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0 https://maven.apache.org/xsd/maven-4.0.0.xsd">
    <modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion>

    <groupId>work.basil.example</groupId>
    <artifactId>WebViewFontProblem</artifactId>
    <version>1.0-SNAPSHOT</version>
    <name>WebViewFontProblem</name>

    <properties>
        <project.build.sourceEncoding>UTF-8</project.build.sourceEncoding>
    </properties>

    <dependencies>
        <!-- https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/org.openjfx/javafx-controls -->
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.openjfx</groupId>
            <artifactId>javafx-controls</artifactId>
            <version>25-ea+14</version>
        </dependency>

        <!-- https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/org.openjfx/javafx-web -->
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.openjfx</groupId>
            <artifactId>javafx-web</artifactId>
            <version>25-ea+14</version>
        </dependency>

        <!-- https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/org.openjfx/javafx-fxml -->
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.openjfx</groupId>
            <artifactId>javafx-fxml</artifactId>
            <version>25-ea+14</version>
        </dependency>

        <!-- https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/org.junit.jupiter/junit-jupiter-api -->
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.junit.jupiter</groupId>
            <artifactId>junit-jupiter-api</artifactId>
            <version>5.13.0-M3</version>
            <scope>test</scope>
        </dependency>

    </dependencies>

    <build>
        <plugins>
            <plugin>
                <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
                <artifactId>maven-compiler-plugin</artifactId>
                <version>3.13.0</version>
                <configuration>
                    <source>24</source>
                    <target>24</target>
                </configuration>
            </plugin>
            <plugin>
                <groupId>org.openjfx</groupId>
                <artifactId>javafx-maven-plugin</artifactId>
                <version>0.0.8</version>
                <executions>
                    <execution>
                        <!-- Default configuration for running with: mvn clean javafx:run -->
                        <id>default-cli</id>
                        <configuration>
                            <mainClass>work.basil.example.webviewfontproblem/work.basil.example.webviewfontproblem.HelloApplication</mainClass>
                            <launcher>app</launcher>
                            <jlinkZipName>app</jlinkZipName>
                            <jlinkImageName>app</jlinkImageName>
                            <noManPages>true</noManPages>
                            <stripDebug>true</stripDebug>
                            <noHeaderFiles>true</noHeaderFiles>
                        </configuration>
                    </execution>
                </executions>
            </plugin>
        </plugins>
    </build>
</project>

question_comments.body: Are you running the app on the same machine as your IDE? Please confirm that you can see the characters in your code editor but not in the JavaFX app.
Edit the Question to specify the host OS and version.
Unfortunately, JavaFX seems to have some severe flaws in its handling of non-Latin characters. I have posted here on the subject, and others too.
Does it work if you change the HTML string to this? <span style="font-family: 'Segoe UI';">გამარჯობა, ეს არის ტესტი.</span>

79604045.body: Thanks for pointing out the correct font. I use auto-font picker and it says Dialog should handle it and it does for all UI elements except WebView. That's what got me stumped.

@forty-two Who said it’s bytes? engine.loadContent(html); loads an HTML document which is already a String and therefore already decoded. No charset decoding takes place. I might have believed that the Java source file had an encoding that was different from what the compiler expected, but the fact that adding a font-family rule fixes things demonstrates otherwise. Also, the “unknown character” boxes have exactly the same count as the original Georgian characters, which almost certainly wouldn’t happen if the source file and the compiler were using different charsets.
@VGR If it's not HTML but just bytes, is it UTF-8? Is it in the standards? And, out of curiosity, how do do you select a suitable font that "maximize Unicode coverage" in reasonable time?

The part about well-formed HTML and encodings is more of an aside in my answer. Possibly a bit of a distraction from the main point (about fonts and the failure of JavaFX/WebKit to pick an appropriate font), but I thought it'd be good to mention them.

It’s pretty clear that this has nothing to do with encodings. Basil is mostly correct in that WebKit is not doing its due diligence; its default stylesheet should search all available fonts in order to maximize Unicode coverage. I don’t think the HTML or CSS standards require doing that, so I don’t know if it’s a bug as much as a poor renderer design. Specifying font-family is a workaround which should not be necessary.

@BasilBourque Hmm, I wonder where the bug is located then. I would expect WebKit—which is the underlying web engine used by JavaFX—to handle the font fallback internally, without much work needed by the JavaFX developers.

The HTML/CSS author can guide the runtime through a list of preferred fonts (a “font stack”) that may or may not exist on the runtime machine.  If none of those suggested fonts provide a glyph for a particular character, the web browser and host OS should find some other font with the needed glyphs. Only if there is no font at all available at runtime offering those glyphs should we see boxes/questions/blanks.

@BasilBourque What I'm finding from some shallow searching on the internet is that the automatic fallback font selection you're talking about has to do with the list of fonts specified by font-family. But what if, like in the questioner's example, the font-family is not defined? Only information I can find is that web browsers will typically fall back to a user-defined or system-wide default font, whatever that font may be. And that font may not be able to display the characters in the webpage.

Webkit, will probably process the input to determine character encoding according to the instructions in the HTML standard. Standard encoding for Java (which I guess could be different from Webkit) is UTF-8 as per JEP 400.

Not a “simple font issue”. Selection of a fallback font for those characters should be automatic. HTML content is not responsible for finding fonts to render the contained characters. Adding a font name within your HTML content is a workaround for a bug.

I called it a "simple font issue" just because the only required modification to get the OP's code to work was to specify an appropriate font. But you're right, there's other things wrong, or at least questionable, about the OP's code. The encoding should be specified and the engine should be passed a well-formed HTML document. Not sure how the engine decides to parse invalid HTML or if that behavior is even documented somewhere, though the underlying engine is WebKit if that means anything.

I would not call it "simply a font issue". (For transparency, I know (almost) nothing about javafx-web). If you have a "web-engine" that is designed to render HTML and when you serve it non-HTML and becomes surprised that the result is gibberish, well, what can you say. In the early days, the character encoding default for HTML was Latin-1, or ISO-8859-1, if I remember correctly. It might have changed to UTF-8 (not sure). But if you don't tell, and the defaults are off, don't be surprised if the result is off as well.

79606103.body: @Slaw I understand and agree. And, that bug report is surprising in that the Georgian characters in particular were problematic but not other Caucasian languages.

Wasn't trying to imply WebKit doesn't target Windows, but the marketing makes it seem like Windows is not a priority. Safari no longer being developed for Windows would only seem to support that (though in that case specifically, I suspect Safari never had enough market penetration to justify the costs; the same may be true of WebKit but, unlike Safari, it's open source).
Historical note… FYI, Apple did ship Safari for Windows OS for five years, over a decade ago.
@Slaw The GitHub site for WebKit lists Windows OS as a build target, and links to this Windows Port page.
I also found this bug: JDK-8087702 – Georgian font is not rendered. The report says it effects Windows 8.

Just to note, I could reproduce the OP's problem on Windows 10 (and my workaround was tested on the same). So, it looks like the problem is platform-specific. I could see WebKit having problems interacting with Windows. It may be cross-platform, but it seems primarily designed for Safari and other macOS/iOS apps. Even the tagline of webkit.org only mentions macOS, iOS, and Linux. Of course, the problem could be with how JavaFX initializes/uses WebKit.
